intro: Chamaesyce mitchelliana, commonly known as Mitchell's sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Portulacaceae and is characterized by its low-growing, sprawling habit with fleshy, succulent leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically greenish-white in color. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in sandy or gravelly soils. Due to its hardy nature, it is sometimes cultivated as an ornamental plant in xeriscapic gardens.
